title: Welcome!
text:
I am an assistant professor in the political science department at the University of Nevada, Reno. I study American political behavior, with research interests in deliberation, political discussion, and political psychology. I have additional research interests in state and local politics, and women and politics. I also study political methodology, with specific interests in experiments and social network analysis. My work has been published in the American Journal of Political Science, the Journal of Experimental Political Science, and PS: Political Science and Politics.
I am co-director of the Nevada Election Survey Project, which conducts original surveys of Nevadans about their political and policy views.
I am Associate Organizer of the Junior Americanist Workshop Series (JAWS). This virtual workshop, which began during the COVID-19 pandemic, provides junior scholars of American politics an opportunity to receive feedback on their work from top scholars in their fields.

title: Media
text:
I have been featured in many local, state, and national media outlets. Here, I offer a sample of these stories.






“Don’t Go Down the Rabbit Hole,” Charlie Warzel, The New York Times, February 18, 2021




“Face the State: Primary Post Mortem,” 2 News, June 23, 2022.
“Breaking Down the Influence of Women in Politics,” KUNR: Nevada Public Radio, November 5, 2020.
“Federal abortion protections at risk in high stakes congressional, Senate races,” The Nevada Independent, March 27, 2022.
“Nevada Latino vote still leans towards Democrats, poll shows,” Las Vegas Review-Journal, November 25, 2022.
“As the election nears, who are you voting for in Nevada?” Nevada Public Radio, November 2, 2022.

title: Teaching
text:
I have over nine years of teaching experience, and teach classes in both American politics and methodology. I am always happy to share syllabi for any of the courses I have taught. Here are my recent course offerings at the University of Nevada:

PSC 101: American Politics: Process and Behavior
PSC 411: Constitutional Law: Separation of Powers and Federalism
PSC 401G/601G: Political Campaigns and Elections
PSC 401F/601F: Public Opinion and Political Behavior
PSC 780: Research Methods in Political Science (graduate)
PSC 208: Survey of State and Local Governments
PSC 401A/601A: Urban Politics
